719648f-a.title: Manhattan: Ericsson Place - Varick Street
719648f-a.text:
36 Ericsson Place (formerly Beach Street), south side,
between Varick and Hudson Street's, showing the home
of Capt. John Ericsson of Civil War (the Monitor) fame.
In 1939 this portion of Beach Street was changed to honor
and commemorate his achievementS.
About 1905
Copywrite Underhill, photographer
Gift of Urbrock Collection
NO REPRODUCTIONS

723721f-a.title: Manhattan: Varick Street - Beach Street
723721f-a.text:
Varick Street, east side, at Beach Street, as seen from Hudson Street,
and across the former site of the New York Central Freight Depot. 9-e
The small 3-story building on the right, is the 4th Precinct Police Station,
and is at the S.W. corner of Ericsson Place (Beach Street).
December 5, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPODUCTIONS.
723721f-a.folder: Varick Street & Beach Street, Manhattan, NY

719645f-a.title: Manhattan: Ericsson Place - Varick Street
719645f-a.text:
20 to 42 Ericsson Place (Beach Street) south side, west from but not
including Varick (left) to Hudson (right) Streets, as seen across clearance
(former site of St. John's Depot) at the N.E. corner of Hudson Street and
Ericsson Place. The small white building (No. 20) on the extreme left
is the 4th Precinct Police Station and is at the S.W. corner of Varick
Street. Shown on the right is an extensive view southward on Hudson
Street from Laight Street. John Ericsson, the inventor and builder of the
famous war-vessel ''Monitor'' resided at one time at what was No. 30 Beach
Street and in his honor this portion which contained his house has been
named Ericsson Place. The site would be in the center,directly in front
of the chimney tower shown.
May 20, 1937.
719645f-a.folder: Ericsson Place & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY

723724f.title: Manhattan: Varick Street - Beach Street
723724f.text:
24 Varick Street, at the S.E. corner of Beach Street. Also shown are
Nos. 14, 12 and 10 Beach Street, at, adioining and east of the S.E. corner
of Varick Street. The new 3-story building at the corner, is also known as
No. 14 Beach Street.
AAbout 1935.
Louis H. Dreyer.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

varick Street, east side, at Beach Street. Also shown is No. 19 Beach

723726f-c.title: Manhattan: Varick Street - Beach Street
723726f-c.text:
(1)
Varick Street, east side, between Beach and Laight Streets, showing
the front of St. John's Chapel, P.E. The railing here shown, was
brought from England. The church has been demolished and on its site
stands now (1937) station V of the United States Post Office. For a
rear view of the Church,see York Street, west from West Broadway to
St. Eohns Lane.
About 1914.
OOift of Samuel Landsman.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(2)
The same, showing a closer view of the front entrance.
About 1914.
Gift o  f Samue  wwY as aaR(6im47'~.
(3)
A portion of the same, showing the gate to the south church yard.
About 1914.
Cift of Samuel Landsnwn.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
